Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(2) Summary

Software engineering and development are changing because IT architecture and landscapes are changing. It used to be the case that organizations were building systems, and the main focus was on integration and how to maintain and evolve those systems. Microservices and other trends show us that this picture is changing: Now it is more about self-contained and independently deployable components which are part of an ecosystem of communicating components. The "glue" in this ecosystem are APIs, which are the only way how these components communicate. How does this shift in architecture affect software design and development? In this presentation we specifically look at how APIs affect both how components provide services, and how they consume them. The goal of this presentation is to allow software developers to better understand how APIs are an essential part of this rather fundamental shift in IT architecture.

From Systems to Ecosystems Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(7) APIs: Old Wine in New Bottles?

  • APIs have been around forever
    • APIs have been part of computers since their very beginning (1940s)
    • Network APIs have been in use since two computers were connected (1950s)
  • Today's APIs are a business strategy and not a technology
    • Establish a platform of digital building blocks that represent your business
    • Adapt to changes by quickly changing or launching products as needed
  • It's not about having APIs, it's about how you're using them
    • Stop betting on snowflakes: Expensive to build and hard to reuse
    • Start betting on platforms: Create and change products effectively


From Systems to Ecosystems Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(8) What is a Platform?



From Systems to Ecosystems Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(9) Software Platforms: Betting on the Network Effect

  • No product is perfect and all products can be improved
  • Building blocks emerge as components of products
  • Product value always must be exposed as a building block
  • There is no network effect without a network


From Systems to Ecosystems Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(10) Jeff Bezos' API Mandate

  1. Data and Capabilities must be exposed through APIs
  2. Team Communications must be through APIs
  3. There can be no side-channels/shortcuts
  4. Technology choice is secondary
  5. APIs must be externalizable


Building Block Culture

Outline (Building Block Culture)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. From Systems to Ecosystems [4]
  3. Building Block Culture [2]
  4. All Products Needs APIs [5]
  5. Conclusions [2]
Building Block Culture Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(12) Consuming Building Blocks

  • Building valuable products should be done as effectively as possible
    • Maximize ratio of effort to build the product and value delivered through the product
  • Consume responsibly and always plan for graceful degradation
    • Risk: Is it worth taking the risk of a dependency?
    • Replacement: Are there plans for temporary/permanent replacements?
    • Redundancy: Is there a failover API to use during outages?
    • Resilience: Is the client handling API problems responsibly?
    • Rightsizing: Is the scope well-defined and at the right size?
    • Representation: Is the client isolating the specific API model?
    • Reporting: Is the dependency monitored for analytics and errors?


Building Block Culture Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(13) Building Building Blocks

  • Always focus on the value of your building blocks
    • What drives product value?
    • How is value exposed to consumers?
    • How can value be reused as a building block?
  • Make it easy to find and consume building blocks
    • A building block that's not used has no network value
    • A building block that's hard to use diminishes its own value


All Products Needs APIs

Outline (All Products Needs APIs)

  1. Introduction [2]
  2. From Systems to Ecosystems [4]
  3. Building Block Culture [2]
  4. All Products Needs APIs [5]
  5. Conclusions [2]
All Products Needs APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(15) On a Platform, Your Product is Your API

  • API Products: Product is more important than API
    • The main focus is on creating and exposing something valuable
    • Value is defined by consumption which means focusing on consumers is important
    • Designing a good API is important but not the deciding factor
  • Doing the Right Thing vs. Doing the Thing Right
    • Doing the Right Thing → Identify capabilities and users as design foundations
    • Doing the Thing Right → Co-design API with consumers to create good DX


All Products Needs APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(16) What is a Product?



All Products Needs APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(17) Always Plan For Extension

  • Your product is going to be improved by you and others
  • Others may have started building on your product
  • Can you evolve your product without impacting others?


All Products Needs APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(18) Always Plan For Augmentation

  • Your product is going to be improved by others
  • Do you make it easy for others to build on your product value?


All Products Needs APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(19) Always Plan For Automation

  • All product features must be available for automation
  • What features cannot be automated and what's the reason?


Conclusions

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development

(21) Build Building Block Culture

  • Try to get as close to a full Bezos [Jeff Bezos' API Mandate (1)] as you can
  • Move from teams competing for success to teams cultivating the platform
  • Make it easy for teams to find [Consuming Building Blocks (1)] and contribute [Building Building Blocks (1)] building blocks
  • Present the building block of the week


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): How APIs Change Software Development
